title: About
text:
I’m Ali Hamza Abidi, a PhD candidate in Applied Mathematics at Texas A&M University, working under the guidance of Dr. Jonathan W. Siegel.
My research connects theoretical mathematics with machine learning, with a focus on approximation theory, optimization, and theoretical deep learning.
My work lies at the intersection of pure mathematics and artificial intelligence. I study how invariant neural networks, transformers, and graph neural networks approximate complex functions, explore sparsity-aware optimization methods for in-context learning and generalizability, and develop computational tools such as scikit-rom, an open-source Python library for reduced-order modeling of PDEs.
I have maintained a 4.0 GPA in my doctoral program following a 3.99 GPA in my undergraduate studies at the University of Houston. My academic performance has been recognized through the Charles P. Benner Scholarship and multiple Academic Excellence Awards.
Beyond research, I serve as a teaching assistant for calculus courses and conduct Python workshops. I am an active member of AMS, SIAM, and Pi Mu Epsilon, and a founding member of Cougar Mathletics and the Theology and Philosophy Academic Club.
Currently, I am preparing publications for venues such as JMLR and ICLR, with contributions on invariant learning and sharpness-aware optimization. My aim is to advance mathematical theory while keeping it practical and impactful for real-world applications.
Fluent in English, Urdu, Hindi, and Arabic, I bring a global perspective to collaborative research and believe that diversity strengthens scientific inquiry.

title: About
text:
Research & Innovation
My work lies at the intersection of pure mathematics and modern AI. Current interests include:

Approximation Theory of Neural Networks — studying how invariant networks, transformers, and graph neural networks approximate complex functions.

Optimization Theory — developing sparsity-aware minimization methods with applications to in-context learning and transformer generalizability.

Computational Mathematics — building open-source tools such as scikit-rom, a Python library for reduced-order modeling to solve PDEs more efficiently.
